title: ple Careers
intro: In this programme, Dan and Neil discuss the trend for having more than one career. They also teach you six items of useful vocabulary. (Image: Getty)
this_week_question: If the surname Baker was originally given to people who worked as bakers, what about those with the surname Bond, as in James Bond? Were they:
Listen to the programme to find out the answer.

vocab.desc: a group or collection of things
used to describe a repeated act, especially a criminal act
someone who starts and runs businesses

vocab.text: add another string to my bow

transcript.author: Neil
transcript.text: Hello and welcome to 6 Minute English – the programme where we bring you an interesting topic and six items of vocabulary. I’m Neil. Today we’re talking about jobs.

transcript.author: Dan
transcript.text: And I’m Dan. And specifically, we’re looking at the trend for having more than one job…

transcript.author: Neil
transcript.text: Yes. On that note – Dan, were you ever asked this question as a kid? “What do you want to be when you grow up?” Do you remember your answer?

transcript.author: Dan
transcript.text: I wanted to be a ninja turtle. And you?

transcript.author: Neil
transcript.text: That doesn’t surprise me. I think I wanted to be a professional footballer. I wanted to play for England. Well, for many people, that question gets harder the older they become! It’s one reason why more and more people have what we call portfolio careers these days – so they can do a bit of everything.

transcript.author: Dan
transcript.text: A portfolio , as a noun, means 'a case for carrying large pictures – or it can mean the collection of pictures themselves. But we also use it as an adjective to describe groups of certain things – in this case, careers.

transcript.author: Neil
transcript.text: Indeed, we could say someone who is a part-time teacher and a part-time musician has a portfolio career.

transcript.author: Dan
transcript.text: Sounds like a good combination. First, let’s do today’s question – it’s job-related. Many surnames in English originally come from professions. The surname Baker, for example, was originally given to people who worked as… bakers! What about the surname Bond, as in double-oh-seven, James Bond? Who had this surname? Was it?

transcript.author: Neil
transcript.text: It can’t be spies, can it? So I’m going to guess guards. C.

transcript.author: Dan
transcript.text: Great, well let’s find out at the end of the programme.

transcript.author: Neil
transcript.text: Now, the portfolio career. Emily Wapnick is the Canadian author of a book called How to Be Everything: A Guide for Those Who (Still) Don’t Know What They Want to Be When They Grow Up.

transcript.author: Dan
transcript.text: Which specific example of a portfolio career does she mention?

transcript.author: INSERT
transcript.text: INSERT Emily Wapnick, Author More and more people are doing multiple things and multiple jobs - and it’s not just to make ends meet . A lot of people are choosing this kind of lifestyle. They’ve got, you know,  three different businesses that are just thriving. Or they’re a serial entrepreneur . Or they’ve got a career in two different areas. There’s a guy that I mention who is a psychotherapist and a luthier – he makes violins - and he’s very successful in both.

transcript.author: Neil
transcript.text: Emily is clearly a fan of this kind of working. She says she knows a man who’s both a psychotherapist and a luthier – someone who makes violins.

transcript.author: Dan
transcript.text: She says this trend is more than just about working to make ends meet – in other words, working to make enough money to live. And she used another interesting expression – a serial entrepreneur – what’s that exactly?

transcript.author: Neil
transcript.text: Well, an entrepreneur is someone who starts and runs businesses – and the use of serial here as an adjective describes someone who does the same thing again and again. Though we should say, the adjective is more often used for criminal activity – such as a serial killer or serial murderer .

transcript.author: Dan
transcript.text: Not the kind of portfolio career I had in mind. A serial entrepreneur , on the other hand, starts and runs business after business.

transcript.author: Neil
transcript.text: Another thing, because Emily believes the world of work is changing fast – it’s sensible to be able to do more than one thing. In other words, it’s wise to add another string to your bow .

transcript.author: Dan
transcript.text: A great phrase, which really just means 'to learn new skills you can use in the future'. I’d like to learn Japanese – that would add another string to my bow .

transcript.author: Neil
transcript.text: So desu, ne? But choosing a portfolio career is not for everyone, of course. It often simply comes down to money.

transcript.author: Dan
transcript.text: Here’s Charles Handy, writer and philosopher, and the man who popularised the term portfolio career in the first place.

transcript.author: INSERT
transcript.text: INSERT Charles Handy, writer 80% of the people in corporate jobs hate them, or are dissatisfied with them. Whereas if you’re doing your own thing, 80% of them really like the freedom and the entrepreneurial spirit, even if they’re not making an awful lot of money. It’s a balancing job really, you’re free but you’re poor. Or you’re slaved but you’re richer.

transcript.author: Neil
transcript.text: Sounds like a difficult choice – be poor or be a slave. What would you choose, Dan?

transcript.author: Dan
transcript.text: I’d rather be poor and free, thank you very much.

transcript.author: Neil
transcript.text: Well, let’s explain a term he used – a corporate job. What does corporate mean?

transcript.author: Dan
transcript.text: Quite literally, it’s the adjective from the term corporation - a corporate job is a job at a big corporation, company or organisation – usually well paid, and with certain benefits.

transcript.author: Neil
transcript.text: Could we say James Bond has a corporate career?

transcript.author: Dan
transcript.text: Yes, I guess so! And thank you for reminding me to answer today’s question: which profession does the surname Bond come from?

transcript.author: Neil
transcript.text: And I said the Bonds were guards.

transcript.author: Dan
transcript.text: I’m afraid you were wrong. Bonds were originally peasant farmers who were bound to work for a particular lord. This word goes back over 1,000 years… the spying game came much later!

transcript.author: Neil
transcript.text: Indeed! Let’s spy today’s words once more. We had portfolio – which can be used in different ways. There’s a portfolio career, as well as the original meaning of a portfolio of art. Any others?

transcript.author: Dan
transcript.text: Yes, people talk about a portfolio of investments – when you invest in several companies at once to reduce the risk.

transcript.author: Neil
transcript.text: Talking of money, we had to make ends meet . People often work a number of different part-time jobs to make ends meet – to make enough money to live on.

transcript.author: Dan
transcript.text: Though having a lot of part-time jobs is not the same as being a serial entrepreneur . Serial means doing something repeatedly, usually a crime!

transcript.author: Neil
transcript.text: And an entrepreneur is someone who starts and runs businesses.

transcript.author: Dan
transcript.text: I’d love to start a business… First, I need to learn a new skill - add another string to my bow and learn yoga. Then maybe one day I’ll run a yoga business.

transcript.author: Neil
transcript.text: Not for me though, I prefer the corporate life – a secure job in a big corporation!

transcript.author: Dan
transcript.text: OK, but then you can come to my yoga classes after work!

transcript.author: Neil
transcript.text: Alright. Dan And that's the end of today's 6 Minute English. Please join us again soon.

transcript.author: Neil
transcript.text: And we are on social media of course. Make sure to visit our Facebook, Twitter, Instagram and YouTube pages.

transcript.author: Both
transcript.text: Bye!
